reviewText: Here's another game for the crap-category in my library. I appreciate the whole retro-aspect and I do dig some of the classic games that are somewhat similar to this (Spy Hunter or Action Fighter for example) - but Organ Biker is a weird mess that fails it's retro-forefathers in every possible way.\n\nA summary of the story or the actual gameplay is hard to do: you collect golden hearts, avoid cars and incoming projectiles and can occasionally throw those hearts into an ambulance for extra points or something. While the first stage seems like there is at least some kind of concept behind it all, subsequent stages are plain weird: I can get hit by missiles and bees, there are +" appearing next to my bike and I can crash into watertowers
date: but I cannot crash into bears or trees. And there is no way to destroy incoming helicopters or attack planes that litter the screen with missiles that don't do anything!? I don't get it
recommended: at all!? What is going on!?\n\nDespite all this
hoursPlayed: I somehow managed to finish story mode
voteText: because after getting past stage 1 (The Highway) it is next to impossible to die unless you crash into things on purpose. But I think I will just leave the game at that  - all in all a waste of time and money."

reviewText: It sort of reminds me of the old NES game Zippy Race.  Pretty straight-forward where you try to get to finish line while dodging obstacles before your hope" (fuel) runs out
date: so you need to determine to either drive slower so you can dodge easier
recommended: or put the pedal to the metal and dodge like crazy to hit the finish line faster.  Later levels essentially turn into one big Bullet Hell dodge-fest where you need to strategically plan to use your special attacks to wipe out the enemies on the screen.  The price point is on the mark

reviewText:
Old-school NES-style game where you dodge obstacles (cars, jets, bullets, bees, bears, etc.) while trying to make it to the finish line. The game has cut-scenes and a story about deliverying organs to hospitals with loads of nostalgia tossed in for good measure. Music and visuals are good. It has a pseudo-CRT effect with scanlines and even a moire effect.

The gameplay is pretty basic but it is EXTREMELY DIFFICULT. Even the first level is quite hard to get past. It respawns you in the busiest lane of traffic and you just get pummeled by a non-stop flow of speeding cars. There is a period of invincibility for a few seconds after respawn but it doesn't always work, sometimes you just die instantly even though your guy is blinking.

On the Xbox 360 controller, the d-pad is used to steer (left/right) and control speed (up/down). Given the famously poor d-pad of the Xbox 360 controller, I often find myself accidentally speeding up or down when trying to steer. That's not the game's fault and in my case, with no other controller options, I think it's actually easier to play this game with a keyboard.

Overall it is simple but frustratingly fun. The furthest I've made it is level 3.

reviewText:
The controls are pretty damned terrible, especially for controllers. The graphics gave me a headache, due to the game trying to emulate a classic CRT TV, which I personally think is a pretty terrible idea.

All in all, I couldn't find this game too enjoyable. It could be good, but it will need a hell of a lot of polishing, and some rethought controls.

Also, pressing pause on a controller completely closes the game, which is a REALLY STUPID IDEA.

reviewText: The game might have been good eventually but the strongest mechanic that brings it down is when you die, you start on the side of the screen. Not a big problem until you realize that enemies can also drive on that side. So everytime you start to move an enemy will crash into you and the inevitable cycle of starting and stopping repeats itself. This could easily be fixed by letting you have invisibility frames after you start moving instead of keeping you in one place for a second and a half. The other problem is the motorcycle moves way too slow. For a precision" game
date: you move a snails pace across the screen. Meanwhile the other cars blaze on by. Might not be a problem but i have had a whole lot of  random factor of 3 trucks catacorned with each other going full speed and you cant dodge that."

reviewText:
9min of this game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nEfIIPmxTgs

you play 3 levels + take down a boss as a organ delivery biker with a death wish who likes to drive the wrong way on roads, travel through military zones, bee nests, and water towers. you have 3 bars to keep track of, mojo (speed), hope (hp/special), & go/end (progress bar). Game play is driving down the road dodging obstacles, collecting hearts/points, & throwing hearts to medivacts until you get the progress bar to the end part. your bike has 7 speeds that will deplete your hope bar slowly or faster if you're not on the road but collecting hearts will give you more hope". if you get close to the side of a vehicle a + will pop up and if you hit it or other object you'll lose "hope"
date: be set to the right side of the road
recommended: & your speed will be dropped to 0. you also lose "hope" if anything hits you. every so often a medivact will show up and a square will be highlighted on the road
hoursPlayed: and you can throw hearts at it if your in the square but you'll lose some "hope" though if you give it 4-5 it will refill about half your bar when it leaves. you do get1 attack if you collect 4 hearts the word hope will flicker and you can clear the screen of most enemies. everything comes at you at random so you never really know whats going to happen."

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9R-gFCQ-4BM

Organ Biker is a very hard game. After an hour of playing I only made it just over halfway through the first level. The tutorial is very vague and mostly leaves it up to the player to discover the mechanics. I loved the old-school graphics and soundtrack. The bits of story I did see were very stylish and fun. The controls were mostly solid, my only frustration coming from the second or two you're forced to wait every time you hit another vehicle. I think if this game had a slightly easier difficulty curve I may have been able to recommend it. It's a shame I wasn't able to see more of this game.

PROS
-cool art and style
-tight soundtrack
-cute story

CONS
-way too difficult
-waiting after you hit another vehicle


DISCLAIMER: Review is based upon approx 1 hour of gameplay.

reviewText:
Note: I only played Arcade mode, but no story could save this game from it's unintuitive gameplay and weird design quirks.

Organ Biker is horrible at communicating with the player. It first launches as a teeny tiny 256x240 window, which is the only place where the game outlines the controls, which make no sense to you if you've never played the game.
Once in the game, what you do is dodge cars (and later missiles from stealth bombers), collect pick-ups and when an ambulance plane" comes on screen
date: you enter the green "launch zone" and shoot hearts at it for points. If you crash
recommended: your bike respawns on the right side of the road
hoursPlayed: and you're invincible for a while.\n\nTo move left or right
voteText: you need to have speed
helpfulPercent: or "MOJO" as the game intuitively calls it. Logically you lose your mojo when you crash
votesHelpful: but your input is disabled for a while after you crash
votesTotal: leaving you watching a flickering stationary bike for a while.\nThe game doesn't in any way indicate the input is disabled
votesFunny: so the first time you'll likely not understand what's going on
column18: the cars *CAN* drive in the part of the road where you respawn. The next time  you'll be manically hammering UP to get your "mojo" on and be able to get out of the way of danger. Why this happens
column19: I have no idea. It definitely doesn't add anything to the game. According to a recent developer announcement
column20: there should be a six seconds invincibility period
column21: but in effect this is usually wasted on waiting for input to become active again.\n\nYour HP is called HOPE
column22: which you refill by picking up heart pick-ups. You lose HOPE over time
column23: whenever you crash and if you get hit by the stealth bombers missiles.\n\nPicking up four heart pick-ups grants you one use of a screen clearing bomb that
column27: I tried using it at the last second
column28: but because the actual clearing of the screen happens after the heart animation has played
column29: I still crashed. Trying go gauge the right time to use the bomb is pretty difficult
column30: and later in the game it's almost useless anyway
column31: because of the time it takes to collect four hearts is very long in relation to the amount of hazards you face.\n\nOrgan Biker doesn't have any animations at all just static sprites (well
column32: the bike sprite gets flipped when you "turn"
column33: but even then the sprite is almost symmetrical). Some of the "old school" effects just look weird (especially the moiré-effect looks like it's just a static texture).\nThe music is very hit and miss
column34: luckily you can choose it manually so you can just opt to never to listen to the worse tracks.\nUnless you disable the arcade-effects
column35: some of the text is pretty hard to read
column36: because your combo and score are not displayed in the same pixel font as the rest of the UI
column37: but instead in a standard serif font
column38: that the arcade effect makes pretty unreadable.\n\nThe game doesn't have a pause function
column39: and no apparent way to quit mid game
column40: appart from just closing the program with Alt+F4.\n\nBottom line is Organ Biker just isn't fun
column41: the controls are iffy and some of the design choices are just arbitary and weird. Apparently the game is still beign worked on
column44: I definitely do not recommend buying it. If there are any updates to the game
column45: I'll make sure to update my review."

reviewText: Beat this game in 12 minutes with no concrete understanding of how it's supposed to be played. I still can't figure out what's going on most of the time. Playing this game well seems to depend upon a combination of moving left and right and accelerating and decelerating at the right times in order to manuever around the various hazards. But Organ Biker is designed so sloppily, is so glitchy, and there's such an absurd amount of obstacles to dodge that I actually don't think it's possible to play it well. Instead, I think the developer just understood that what they were asking the player to suffer through was impossible, so they just made the entire thing really forgiving. This retro-inspired overlay isn't doing the game any favors either, make that ♥♥♥♥ optional. Not everyone is a 20-something hipster that wanks to scanlines and CRTs and overpays for physical copies of games they've never played but still fondly reminisce over.

reviewText:
Really bad game, just really bad.

It tries to be like the old nes/atari games but the gameplay is horible. Even if you go past the fake crt screen look that hurts the eyes and the generic 8-bit music, the gameplay is a mess.
You ride a bike, you change speed like in the classic outrun game (you have 3 tiers of speed here) and you try to avoid cars and helicopters and collect points and hearts by going left and right. You also have an attack. The cars are all over the place and some helicopters are shooting projectiles at you and the screen is just a big cluster♥♥♥♥. You just have to avoid as many cars as possible while you try to collect the hearts. there are only 4 super sort stages, a horible boss fight and some childish funny" story.

This is one of these games you would expect to find free from someone that made it from fun in his free time. Sure the price is very low but even if this was free it would still be bad."

reviewText:
English -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This game had everything to be good, but leaves the whole concept of old-school nes-style sink like the Titanic.

The controls are horrible. Try to use the concept of Retro game, but the gameplay is horrible.

To leave the game in a tiny resolution? The sound is horrible. The joystick does not work, at least in NES I used the joystick.

Even a child who is learning how to make games can do better.

My opinion. Do not buy this game.


Português BR ---------------------------------------------------------
Este jogo tinha tudo para ser bom, mas deixa todo o conceito de old-school nes-style afundar igual o Titanic.

Os controles são horríveis. Tenta usar o conceito de Jogo Retro, mas a jogabilidade é horrivel.

Para que deixar o jogo em uma resolução minuscula? O Som é horrivel. O joystick não funciona, pelo menos no NES eu usava o joystick.

Até mesmo uma criança que está aprendendo a fazer jogos consegue fazer algo melhor.

Minha opinião. Não compre este jogo.
